An update for those that don't read the papers. McCain won Florida, and Giuliani is dropping out of the race and backing McCain now. Clinton "won" Florida also. I put won in quotes because Florida lost its Democratic delegates, so the win is pretty much symbolic. The other candidates didn't even campaign there. 
 
 I'm surprised that Guiliani did so poorly. I don't like his politics, but I recognise his skill as a politician. Was he just too centrist for today's republican party, being on the wrong side of several issues from the conservtive point of view? Any thoughts?

 Well, things aren't over just yet, but your prediction is probably right. Looks like we'll have 2 senators running against each other. Of course, saying that the popularity of the senate as a whole has anything to do with the popularity of those running doesn't really follow. Bush is the president; Obama, Clinton and McCain aren't the senate. And most of them are touting change to one degree or another, and lack of change is the reason the current senate isn't all that popular. So no, I don't really see anything odd about it at all.

 Again, you're overgeneralizing. Even if we say that the senate is causing problems, you need to ask which bills exactly were the problem ones and how did the candidates vote on those bills. Depending on what you consider problematic one of the candidates may have voted in exactly the way you consider correct. If you just say "senate bad, so all senators bad" then you're painting with far too broad a stroke.

 Hey! Don't dump all the blame on my shoulders! I don't have that much influence. :)
 
 
 
 You know how you regain a status in the world? By minding your own business and having a strong economy. You know you have a strong economy and mind your own business? You stop spending money. 

 
 Just for the record, I'm not against financial responsibility. But tighteneing the purse strings is not going to regain the world's respect. Treating our allies with respect even when they disagree with us, working with the world community instead of acting unilaterally, sticking to the moral high ground even when we can get away with doing otherwise. That's how you maintain your position as world leader.

Hey! Don't dump all the blame on my shoulders! I don't have that much influence. :)
I'm not! I'm blaming the Congress over the last 15-20 years. I just think if we don't make it a priority there will be no county to regain foreign relations in, there will be no country to get married in, there will be no country to outlaw abortion in. 
 
 I just don't think people get how serious of a problem it is. Of course why should I get it when many Americans do the same thing by buying a house they can't afford and then not knowing that until its too late.
 
 
But tighteneing the purse strings is not going to regain the world's respect.
No, it will save our economy and bring a stronger dollar and bring a more productive state which in return regains the world's respect. Look at China...everyone respects them (they may not like them) but its because of their productivity. 
 
 
Treating our allies with respect even when they disagree with us, working with the world community instead of acting unilaterally, sticking to the moral high ground even when we can get away with doing otherwise. That's how you maintain your position as world leader.
This strategy doesn't work unless you have stuff that another country needs. You expect a buddy buddy system and "lets all just get along" but unfortunately it won't work that way. Daewoo, I believe, was the first to kinda bring this idea to my attention and perhaps he can add a little more. In the end, you are right in that we need to stop poking our nose where it doesn't belong and at least be kind but firm with our neighbors but that only goes so far.

I'd say a restraint fiscally would naturally cause better foreign relations. 

 I just don't see that being a huge factor. It might help some, but if my goal was to improve foreign relations reigning in spending would not be the first approach i would take. Can you expand on your reasoning?
 
 

 Hard to make people happy when you attack other countries causing you to spend well into debt thus lowering your economy and bringing other economies with it.
 

 
 The start of that chain is belligerence, not out of control spending. Seems to me that if you want to control spending you should work on foreign relations. That way you get into fewer wars, and when you must fight you have others helping and sharing the cost.
